1 Introduction
The notion of immunological homeostasis pertains to the delicate balance between the 
activation and inhibition of the immune system. Immunotherapy by monoclonal anti -
bodies is designed to effectively identify and eliminate infections during an illness while Discover Oncology
Abstract
Extracellular adenosine has recently been identified as an immunological checkpoint 
mediator that hinders the immune response to malignancies. The production of 
adenosine is facilitated by the enzymatic activity of CD39 and CD73. There is an 
increasing body of evidence suggesting that CD39 and CD73, which ar

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
mmune response to malignancies. The production of 
adenosine is facilitated by the enzymatic activity of CD39 and CD73. There is an 
increasing body of evidence suggesting that CD39 and CD73, which are considered 
to be emerging immunological checkpoints, can transform adenosine triphosphate 
(ATP)-mediated pro-inflammatory tumor microenvironment (TME) into an adenosine-
mediated immunosuppressive through purinergic pathway. The aim of this study 
was to review macrophages-based cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 
and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoints. We searched the PubMed, EMBASE, 
Web of Science, and Medline (Ovid) databases to find relevant studies between 
December 30, 2010, and December 30, 2024. The search strategy encompassed 
utilization of Cancer, Immune checkpoints, CD39, CD73, Immunotherapy as keywords. 
The case reports, reviews, evaluations, originals, and earlier meta-analyses were all 
included in the study. The inclusion criteria were the researches that investigated 
the functions of the adenosinergic immunological checkpoints CD39 and CD73 in 
cancer immunotherapy. Clinical studies have examined small molecule inhibitors 
or monoclonal antibodies that

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
estigated 
the functions of the adenosinergic immunological checkpoints CD39 and CD73 in 
cancer immunotherapy. Clinical studies have examined small molecule inhibitors 
or monoclonal antibodies that target the CD39/CD73 pathway in recent years. 
Cancer immunotherapy might profit from therapeutic inhibition of CD39 and CD73’s 
enzymatic activity, given that these two proteins are crucial for the conversion of ATP 
into adenosine. Multiple types of monoclonal antibodies have been developed and 
shown to inhibit CD39 or CD73. One benefit of using monoclonal antibodies to block 
CD39 and CD73 is that antibody medications usually have lengthy serum half-lives. 
Inhibiting CD39 and CD73 may contribute to limiting the progression of tumors 
and boost anti-tumor responses. Currently, one of the most promising strategies 
in immuno-oncology is to target CD39 and CD73 due to their extensive immune 
regulatory effects on tumor immunity.
Keywords  Cancer, Immune checkpoints, CD39, CD73, Immunotherapy

rapy

Yin et al. Discover Oncology          (2025) 16:2153 
minimizing exaggerated and incorrect immune responses that could potentially harm 
the body’s tissues. A growing body of academic literature indicates a strong correlation 
between the disruption of immunological balance and the majority of cancer cases [ 1]. 
The principal function of immunological checkpoints is their ability to govern tissue 
damage during the innate immune system’s physiological response to combat pathogenic 
infections, primarily by modulating the inflammatory response. The immune checkpoint 
pathways have considerable activity within cancer cells, hence enabling the evasion of 
immunological responses by malignant tumors [ 2]. The immune system utilizes various 
immunological checkpoint molecules comprising ligand-receptor pairs. These chemi -
cal substances have the capacity to either impede or enhance immune responses. These 
compounds are broadly distributed across several cell types, encompassing immune 
cells, antigen-presenting cells, tumor cells, and other cellular entities. As a result, they 
assume a pivotal function in controlling adaptive immune system development, specifi -

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
compassing immune 
cells, antigen-presenting cells, tumor cells, and other cellular entities. As a result, they 
assume a pivotal function in controlling adaptive immune system development, specifi -
cally T cells and innate immune cells. An expanding corpus of scholarly literature has 
revealed an increasingly diverse set of immunological checkpoints, including but not 
limited to programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1), programmed cell death-ligand 1 
(PD-L1), cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein 4 (CTLA-4), lymphocyte activa -
tion gene-3 (LAG-3), T cell immunoglobulin domain and mucin domain-3 (TIM-3), and 
tumor-infiltrating lymphocyte (TIL) [ 3, 4]. The application of immune checkpoint block -
ade therapy, which aims to activate the suppressed immune response against tumors, 
represents a notable advancement in oncological intervention [ 5].
The proteins CD39 and CD73 play a crucial role in the enzymatic conversion of 
adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to adenosine. Consequently, they fulfill a vital role in 
the regulation of immunological suppression. The enzymatic conversion of adenosine 
diphosphate (ADP) to adenosine is attributed to CD73, whereas CD39 enhances the con -

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
they fulfill a vital role in 
the regulation of immunological suppression. The enzymatic conversion of adenosine 
diphosphate (ADP) to adenosine is attributed to CD73, whereas CD39 enhances the con -
version of ATP to ADP [ 6, 7]. The significant involvement of CD39 and CD73 in the syn -
thesis of adenosine, resulting in the creation of an immunosuppressive environment, is 
widely recognized [ 8]. Previous studies have demonstrated the anti-inflammatory prop -
erties of adenosine, particularly when it is released into the extracellular environment 
[9]. The significance of the interaction between specific T cell receptors and adenosine 
in the inhibition of antitumor immune response is quite significant. Tumor formation 
was reported to be suppressed following the inhibition of CD39 and CD73. The control 
of immunological reactions can be achieved by reducing the enzymatic activity of CD39 
and CD73, suppressing adenosine production [ 10, 11]. The metabolic control of ATP 
and adenosine by CD39 and CD73 are presented in Fig. 1.
The efficacy of immunotherapies involving CD39 and CD73 can be ascribed to their 
capacity to impede the production of immunosuppressive adenosine and the d

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
e by CD39 and CD73 are presented in Fig. 1.
The efficacy of immunotherapies involving CD39 and CD73 can be ascribed to their 
capacity to impede the production of immunosuppressive adenosine and the degrada -
tion of extracellular ATP . The application of this specific strategy exhibits potential as 
an immunotherapeutic approach that can augment the efficacy of immune checkpoint 
inhibitors in the context of combination therapy. This article succinctly summarizes the 
cellular and molecular mechanisms linked to the CD39 and CD73 pathways. Moreover, 
the primary objective of this work is to investigate the current status of therapeutic inter -
ventions targeting the CD39/CD73 adenosine pathway while also proposing prospective 
strategies to enhance the efficacy of cancer treatment in forthcoming advancements.

2 Methodology
In the present article, we reviewed the application of adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as 
new immunological checkpoints in macrophage-based cancer immunotherapy. Between 
December 30, 2010, and December 30, 2024, we thoroughly searched all of the major 
databases, including Medline (Ovid), Embase, P

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
logical checkpoints in macrophage-based cancer immunotherapy. Between 
December 30, 2010, and December 30, 2024, we thoroughly searched all of the major 
databases, including Medline (Ovid), Embase, PubMed, and Web of Science. With an 
emphasis on examining the purposes and applications of CD39 and CD73 in cancer 
immunotherapy, our search included research that was published in all languages. Can -
cer, Immune checkpoints, CD39, CD73, and immunotherapy were all included as key -
words in the literature’s title and abstract as part of the search strategy. Additionally, we 
evaluated two additional sources to confirm the studies’ applicability: (I) the references 
of numerous approved review papers and (II) the references of articles that might be 
qualified. The inclusion/exclusion criteria include: an assortment of research that inves -
tigated the functions of the adenosinergic immunological checkpoints CD39 and CD73 
in cancer immunotherapy. Moreover, case reports, reviews, evaluations, originals, and 
earlier meta-analyses were all included in the study. The article that covered the most 
important subjects was chosen for inclusion when several publications with compara -

3 Biology and biochemistry CD39/CD73
CD39 is a crucial transmembrane enzyme that relies on the presence of calcium (Ca2+) 
and magnesium (Mg2+) ions for its functionality. The process operates through the 
catalysis of ATP phosphohydrolysis, leading to the synthesis of adenosine monophos -
phate [ 12, 13]. The protein CD39 is composed of a total of 510 amino acids, which 
includes seven notable N-glycosylation sites, 11 cysteine residues, and sites that are situ -
ated within the inner membrane [ 14–16]. CD39 is comprised of five conserved regions 
called apyrase domains, which are essential for the formation of the active site and the 
catalytic process involved in the phosphohydrolysis of extracellular nucleotides [ 17–
19]. CD39 is predominantly expressed by several cell types, including endothelial cells, 
immunological cells, such as dendritic cells (DCs), Langerhans cells, neutrophils, B cells, 
monoc

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
tides [ 17–
19]. CD39 is predominantly expressed by several cell types, including endothelial cells, 
immunological cells, such as dendritic cells (DCs), Langerhans cells, neutrophils, B cells, 
monocytes, natural killer (NK) cells, macrophages, mesangial cells, and regulatory T 
(Tregs) cells [ 20–22]. The expression of CD39 is modulated by multiple variables, such 
as proinflammatory cytokines, hypoxia, oxidative stress, specificity protein 1 (Sp1), and 
signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) [ 23, 24]. The enzyme CD73, 
which is anchored to glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI), plays a pivotal role in facili -
tating the conversion of adenosine monophosphate (AMP) to adenosine and inorganic 
phosphate [ 25]. After the elimination of the GPI anchor, the soluble form of CD73 has a 
function comparable to that of its membrane-bound form [ 26]. CD73 consists of three 
discrete domains: an N-terminal domain containing metal-binding sites, a C-terminus 
domain housing the catalytic site, and a short alpha helix connecting the N and C-ter -
minal domains [ 27, 28]. CD73 is a GPI-anchored molecule with a molecular weight of 
70 kD. The regulation of adenosinergic signa

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
e catalytic site, and a short alpha helix connecting the N and C-ter -
minal domains [ 27, 28]. CD73 is a GPI-anchored molecule with a molecular weight of 
70 kD. The regulation of adenosinergic signaling is greatly impacted by its engagement 
[29, 30]. CD73 has been detected in multiple organs and cell types, including the brain, 
colon, kidney, heart, liver, lung, and leukocytes [ 31–33].
4 Tumor microenvironment
The tumor microenvironment comprises several cellular components, such as tumor 
cells, stromal cells, endothelial cells, and immune cells, which demonstrate increased 
expression of CD39 and CD73 [ 34]. It is crucial to acknowledge that this particular gene 
has been documented to have increased levels of expression inside a hypoxic tumor 
microenvironment. In addition, current research has uncovered that Tregs significantly 
impact the upregulation of CD39 and CD73 expression in response to adenosine sig -
naling [ 35, 36]. The process described above establishes a feedback loop that sustains 
the generation of adenosine and the immunosuppressive state inside the tumor micro -
environment [ 37, 38]. Elevated levels of CD39 and CD73 have been observed in neo -
plastic c

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
k loop that sustains 
the generation of adenosine and the immunosuppressive state inside the tumor micro -
environment [ 37, 38]. Elevated levels of CD39 and CD73 have been observed in neo -
plastic cells, immunological cells, endothelial cells, and fibroblasts. Furthermore, it is 
crucial to recognize that tumors consistently release exosomes that include CD39 and 
CD73, leading to a increased presence of ectonucleotidases inside the distinct tumor 
microenvironment.
Recent studies have yielded empirical findings suggesting that exosomes originating 
from cancer cells manifest the presence of CD39 and CD73 proteins on their cellular 
membrane. Moreover, exosomes originating from several cancer types demonstrate sig -
nificant hydrolytic activity towards ATP and AMP-phosphate. Prior studies have dem -
onstrated that the observed elevation in adenosine concentrations inside the tumor 
microenvironment can be ascribed to enzymatic processes [ 39, 40]. The expression of

CD39 and CD73 on myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) inside the tumor micro -

CD39 and CD73 on myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) inside the tumor micro -
environment is subject to regulation by transforming growth factor beta (TGF-β) and 
hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1) [ 41, 42]. Recent studies have demonstrated 
that increased levels of immunosuppressive adenosine inside the tumor microenviron -
ment play a substantial role in enabling cancer cells to evade the immune system. Hence, 
the CD39/CD73/adenosine pathway facilitates the buildup of increased extracellular 
adenosine concentrations inside the tumor microenvironment [ 43].
5 Human cancers
5.1 Solid tumours
Several studies have suggested that CD39 may serve as a prognostic indicator, as it is 
found in both human malignancies and the immune cells that infiltrate these tumors. 
Pancreatic cancer cases have exhibited a notable tendency towards the upregulation of 
CD39 in both the vascular and stromal constituents. According to a study conducted 
by researchers [ 44], an empirical investigation has revealed a significant correlation 
between increased levels of CD39 mRNA in tissue and improved long-term survival out -
comes following t

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
ducted 
by researchers [ 44], an empirical investigation has revealed a significant correlation 
between increased levels of CD39 mRNA in tissue and improved long-term survival out -
comes following tumor removal. The investigation of rectal cancer in human patients 
has revealed a significant increase in the expression of CD39 in both primary tumors 
and metastatic sites. Nevertheless, a proposition was presented, positing that the con -
current assessment of CD39 and CD73 would yield a more precise prognostic marker in 
contrast to the sole evaluation of CD39 [ 45].
The upregulation of CD73 has been associated with multiple signaling pathways that 
are involved in the advancement of tumors. These pathways include Wnt [ 46], epithelial-
to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) [ 47], TP53 [ 48] or Kirsten rat sarcoma virus (KRAS) 
mutations [ 49], TGF-β [ 50], and loss of estrogen receptor signaling [ 51]. As a result, the 
accumulation of adenosine within the tumor, facilitated by the enzyme CD73, impedes 
the immune system’s ability to effectively launch responses against the tumor [ 39]. A 
comprehensive examination has been undertaken to explore the correlation between the 
expression

CD73, impedes 
the immune system’s ability to effectively launch responses against the tumor [ 39]. A 
comprehensive examination has been undertaken to explore the correlation between the 
expression of CD73 and various clinicopathological characteristics in multiple cancer 
types, including melanoma, breast cancer, acute lymphocytic leukemia, chronic lympho -
cytic leukemia (CLL), glioblastoma, head and neck cancers, high-grade serous ovarian 
cancer, endometrial cancer, colorectal cancer, prostate cancer, bladder cancer, gastric 
cancer, kidney cancer, and pancreatic carcinomas [ 52, 53]. The results of these analyses 
consistently indicate a notable correlation between increased levels of CD73 expression 
in the tumor microenvironment and unfavorable clinical outcomes. Recent studies have 
demonstrated that individuals who have received a diagnosis of cancer exhibit elevated 
levels of soluble CD73 in their plasma, in contrast to persons who are in a state of good 
health [ 54]. Moreover, it has been observed that persons diagnosed with acute inflam -
matory pancreatitis exhibit increased concentrations of soluble CD73 in their circula -
tory system [ 55]. Hence, the identificat

eover, it has been observed that persons diagnosed with acute inflam -
matory pancreatitis exhibit increased concentrations of soluble CD73 in their circula -
tory system [ 55]. Hence, the identification of increased concentrations of soluble CD73 
in the bloodstream has the potential to serve as a diagnostic indicator for inflammation 
in tissues or tumors.
The interplay between neoplastic cells and their surrounding microenvironment is a 
pivotal factor in shaping the progression and metastasis of the tumor [ 56]. CD39 has 
been observed in invading immune cells and cancer cells in several human malignancies, 
such as lung cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck, clear cell carcinoma

of the kidney, rectal adenocarcinoma, thyroid cancer, breast cancer, and multiform glio -

The prognostic implications of CD73 expression within the tumor microenvironment 
have been examined in a range of tumor types, including lung squamous cell c

text:
D39 expression and an adverse prognosis. 
The prognostic implications of CD73 expression within the tumor microenvironment 
have been examined in a range of tumor types, including lung squamous cell carci -
noma, pheochromocytoma, pancreatic cancer, bladder urothelial carcinoma, esophageal 
carcinoma, gastric adenocarcinoma, thyroid carcinoma, and pleomorphic glioblas -
toma. The conducted study has demonstrated a notable correlation between elevated 
CD73 expression and the progression of metastasis, leading to a reduction in the dura -
tion until recurrence [ 58]. Several studies have provided evidence of an increase in the 
expression of CD39 and CD73 in various cancer types as compared to the surrounding 
normal tissues. Furthermore, previous studies have provided evidence of a significant 
association between the activation of the CD39/CD73 pathway and the presence of an 
immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, as well as a negative prognosis, in cancer 
patients [ 59]. Therefore, it is crucial to emphasize the importance of CD39 and CD73 
in the regulatory mechanisms that control the proliferation, differentiation, migration, 
and infiltration of malignant cells [ 60, 61].

in the regulatory mechanisms that control the proliferation, differentiation, migration,

of cancer cells to evade immune detection. The observed phenomena can be ascribed to 
the role of these chemicals in facilitating the infiltration of MDSCs and Treg cells into 
the specific tumor microenvironment [ 61, 62].
Surgically excised tumors of hepatocellular carcinoma, gastric carcinoma, and head 
and neck squamous cell carcinoma have exhibited increased levels of CD39. Based on 
the extant empirical evidence, it may be inferred that there exists a positive correlation 
between increased levels of CD39 expression and an augmented probability of postop -
erative recurrence and/or unfavorable overall survival outcomes. In addition, a recent 
empirical study has provided empirical evidence suggesting that the inclusion of FoxP3 
+ Tregs expressing CD39 demonstrates improved prognostic effectiveness in predicting 
the survival rate in gastric cancer an

5.2 Hematological malignancies
In the context of hematological malignancies, previous studies have demonstrated a 
higher prevalence of CD39+, CD4+, and CD8 + cells in follicular lymphoma, as opposed 
to their significantly reduced presence in healthy or reactive lymph nodes, as well as in 
normal peripheral blood [ 65]. The research undertaken by the scientists has established 
a favorable correlation between elevated CD39 expression on CD4 + and CD8 + cells 
derived from individuals diagnosed with CLL and a higher stage of the ailment [ 66].
6 Cancer immunotherapy
A considerable amount of research has been conducted, which suggests that inside the 
tumor microenvironment, many cell types, such as cancer c

6 Cancer immunotherapy
A considerable amount of research has been conducted, which suggests that inside the 
tumor microenvironment, many cell types, such as cancer cells, immune cell subsets, 
and stromal cells, demonstrate increased expression of CD39 and CD73. The prevailing 
idea suggests that the observed upregulation of these molecules functions as an adap -
tive mechanism employed by these cells to hinder the immune response directed toward 
cancerous cells. The methodology outlined in the aforementioned study induces a rise 
in adenosine concentrations, inhibiting immune reactions targeting tumors [ 40]. Con -
sequently, there has been a growing inclination towards employing the CD39/CD73 axis 
as an immunotherapeutic approach to diminish adenosine levels and facilitate the tran -
sition of cells from a pro-tumoral condition to an anti-tumoral immune response (Fig. 
2). Given the claimed role of CD73 and CD39 as adhesion molecules, it is reasonable

of research has provided empirical evidence that supports a positive link between the 
expression and/or activity of CD73 and the capacity of malignant cells to adhere to the 
extracellular matrix and invade various tissues. Previous studies have demonstrated that 
inhibiting CD39 and CD73 enzymatic activity significantly reduces tumor development 
and metastasis by decreasing tumor angiogenesis [ 73].
Furthermore, considerable empirical data indicates that the inhibition of CD73 can 
directly augment the effectiveness of conventional therapeutic approaches. The desired 
result can be achieved by employing particular strategies that directly focus on cancer 
cells or by decreasing adenosine levels, thus indirectly enhancing the effectiveness of 
immune cells in inhibiting tumor growth. The abovementioned technique has shown 
promise in improving the immunosuppressed microenvironment [ 74]. There is an on

immune cells in inhibiting tumor growth. The abovementioned technique has shown 
promise in improving the immunosuppressed microenvironment [ 74]. There is an ongo -
ing evaluation of the inhibitory impacts exerted on CD73 by applying monoclonal anti -
bodies. Significantly, the examined antibodies encompass oleclumab, CPI-006, AK119, 
TJ004309, NZV929, and BMS-986,179. Moreover, ongoing clinical trials are underway 
to assess synthetic inhibitors’ effectiveness, such as LY3475070 and AB-680. The current 
evaluation of the bifunctional monoclonal antibody GS-1423, which exhibits selectivity 
for the CD73 and TGF-β pathways, is in progress. The primary focus of research regard -
ing these substances revolves around their potential utilization as a combined treatment 
approach for patients diagnosed with advanced cancer. Monoclonal antibodies have 
demonstrated a reduced incidence of off-target effects compared to naturally occurring 
or chemically synthesized inhibitors targeting CD73. In contrast to monoclonal anti -
bodies, conventional molecular inhibitors such as ARL67156/POM-1 (CD39), AMPCP 
(CD73), and their derivatives have been utilized

bodies, conventional molecular inhibitors such as ARL67156/POM-1 (CD39), AMPCP

7 Combination therapy
7.1 Combination therapy by CD39
Concurrently with notable advancements in the clinical field and the extensive imple -
mentation of research pertaining to combination therapy, several strategies involving 
the simultaneous administration of multiple medications are being utilized in clinical 
settings [ 76]. Considering its unique capacity to regulate homeostasis within the tumor 
microenvironment through the preservation of pro-inflammatory ATP and the reduc -
tion of adenosine accumulation, it is advisable to prioritize the suppression of CD39 in 
the context of combination therapy.
There is a growing acknowledgment of the potential effectiveness of combining the 
ATP-adenosine axis with chemotherapy. Prior research has yielded findings about 
the correlation between the release of ATP resulting from cellular breakdown or

In a manner akin to the action of chemotherapy, radiation induces the release of ATP 
from numerous degenerating neoplastic cells. Following this, ATP undergoes enzy -
matic conversion assisted by the CD39 and CD73 enzymes, leading to the synthesis of 
adenosine. The adenosine-mediated pathways have the potential to hinder the immune 
responses directed toward cancers that are triggered by radiation [ 87]. Therefore, there 
is a strong rationale for employing a diverse range of inhibitors that selectively target 
the adenosine system in conjunction with radiation therapy in order to attain improved 
effectiveness in the management of neoplasms. Additional research is necessary to 
explore the potential integration of CD39 inhibitors within the context of radiation 
therapy. Nevertheless, it is crucial to exercise prudence when evaluating the possible

7.2 Combination therapy by CD73
In recent times, CD73 has garnered significant attention as a prospective candidate for 
a novel therapeutic strategy incorporating combination therapy, owing to its pivotal 
involvement in the immune response against malignancies [ 89, 90]. Regarding this issue, 
in addition to conventional therapy, there is continuous assessment of various anti-
CD73 antibodies and other selective small-molecule inhibitors. The study’s findings sug -
gest potential avenues for enhancing therapeutic strategies that target CD73-mediated 
adenosine signaling in combination with existing cancer therapies.
Previous studies have documented the correlation between CD73 and multidrug resis -
tance [ 91]. The stud

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
that target CD73-mediated 
adenosine signaling in combination with existing cancer therapies.
Previous studies have documented the correlation between CD73 and multidrug resis -
tance [ 91]. The study revealed a significant association between the presence of CD73 
and the acquisition of resistance to doxorubicin in patients afflicted with triple-negative 
breast cancer (TNBC). The treatment of doxorubicin led to an increase in the expres -
sion of CD73, which subsequently resulted in the inhibition of CD8 + T cells [ 51]. The 
study reported an increased abundance of CD47+/CD73+/PDL + cells in TNBC cells 
following treatment with adjunctive chemotherapeutic agents, namely carboplatin, 
gemcitabine, and paclitaxel [ 92]. The investigation into the sensitivity of chemothera -
peutic drugs in NCI-60 cell lines revealed a negative correlation between the expression 
of CD73 and the vulnerability to different chemotherapeutic agents. In addition, it was 
noted that there was an elevation in the expression of CD73 in ovarian cancer cells that 
exhibited resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy [ 93]. Moreover, there have been 
reports suggesting that the cytokine interleukin-6 (IL-6)

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
in the expression of CD73 in ovarian cancer cells that 
exhibited resistance to platinum-based chemotherapy [ 93]. Moreover, there have been 
reports suggesting that the cytokine interleukin-6 (IL-6) derived from mesenchymal 
stem/stromal cells has a significant role in facilitating resistance to cisplatin in nasopha -
ryngeal cancer by upregulating CD73 [ 94]. The rise in CD73 expression seen subsequent 
to chemotherapy treatment appears to be a method utilized by the organism to counter -
balance the excessive release of ATP by neoplastic cells in reaction to chemotherapy [ 80, 
95]. Moreover, it is apparent that the conveyance of adenosine via CD73 results in the 
suppression of ABC transporters and P-glycoprotein, a transporter accountable for the 
expulsion of drugs. Hence, this particular mechanism contributes to the emergence of 
drug resistance [ 96, 97].
Several studies have demonstrated enhanced efficacy in certain mouse tumor mod -
els when combining anti-CD73 with PD-L1 and/or anti-CTLA-4, as opposed to utiliz -
ing anti-CD73 monotherapy [ 98–100]. The findings from a comprehensive examination 
of the immune system suggest that individuals diagnosed with glioblastoma wh

of the immune system suggest that individuals diagnosed with glioblastoma who have 
undergone anti-PD-1 therapy exhibit a notable presence of macrophages characterized 
by elevated levels of CD73. The researchers discovered that the lack of CD73 resulted in 
an increased efficacy of anti-PD-1 and anti-CTLA-4 therapies in a murine model of glio -

monoclonal antibody resulted in the augmentation of anticancer effects. The combined

antibody exhibited significant inhibition of melanoma tumor growth in mice, surpass -

simultaneous suppression of CD73 and CTLA-4 led to a notable increase in the number

Moreover, it is worth noting that radiation therapy has the capacity to influence the 
immune response in addition to its direct cytotoxic impact on cancer cells [ 103]. The 
exposure to radiation led to the initiation of programmed cell death (apoptosis) in NK 
cells, T cells, and B cells, as well as the simultaneous attraction and stimulation of DCs 
[104]. The observed variation in immunological regulation resulting from radiation 
exposure is most likely attributable to the relative proportions of ATP and adenosine. It 
is important to acknowledge that there exists a link between increased CD73 enzymatic 
activity in lung tissue exposed to radiation and the occurrence of pulmonary fibrosis, 
a notable detrimental consequence of thoracic irradiation. The infusion of anti-CD73 
antibodies led to a notable reduction in radiation-induced lung fibrosis, as reported in 
a study [ 105]. This discovery suggests that the inhibition of CD73 may be a promisi

antibodies led to a notable reduction in radiation-induced lung fibrosis, as reported in

strategy for alleviating the pulmonary adverse effects commonly observed in the treat -
ment of thoracic cancer. Additionally, it was noted that the application of radiotherapy 
led to an increase in the expression of CD73 in human breast cancer cells. Furthermore, 
a study indicated that the concurrent inhibition of CD73 and radiation demonstrated an 
enhanced modulation of antitumor T cell responses [ 106]. Nevertheless, recent research 
has demonstrated that the pharmacological inhibition or ablation of CD73 can suc -
cessfully reinstate the proliferative capacity of human bladder cancer cells, leading to a 
reduction in their susceptibility to radiation [ 107].
8 Clinical trials
8.1 Clinical trials in CD39
Several phase I clinical trials have been undertaken to evaluate the effectiveness of CD39 
monoclonal antibodies or other inhibitors, either as monotherapy or in combination 
with other inhibitors, for various types of solid tumor malignancies. The current clini -
cal trials

istration codes, namely NCT05508373, NCT05381935, and NCT05234853. In addition, 
there are now active clinical trials aimed at evaluating the effectiveness of four CD39

findings have demonstrated promising indications within the realm of cancer therapy. 
Despite being a component of the immunotherapy field, CD39 inhibitors have received 
limited attention in the arena of clinical research (Table  1).

8.2 Clinical trials in CD73
A multitude of treatment trials have been conducted with monoclonal antibodies that 
specifically target CD73, with the objective of addressing various types of solid tumors. 
The injection of

n CD73
A multitude of treatment trials have been conducted with monoclonal antibodies that 
specifically target CD73, with the objective of addressing various types of solid tumors. 
The injection of these antibodies has been reported in several therapeutic applications, 
both independently and in conjunction with medications that particularly target PD-L1 
or PD-1. Oleclumab, MEDI9447, AK119, HLX23, IPH5301, Sym042, CPI-0006, IBI325, 
PT199, JAB-BX102, TJ004309, NZV930, INCA00186, and BMS-986,179 represent a 
diverse range of antibody compounds. The association between anti-CD73 and moder -
ate side effects, which have been demonstrated to be manageable or acceptable, has been 
documented in several clinical trials (NCT02503774, NCT03381274, NCT03616886, 
NCT03611556, and NCT03334617). The preliminary findings have yielded inconclusive 
outcomes, as certain examinations have exhibited encouraging signs of disease control, 
but others have failed to establish unequivocal therapeutic advantages (Table  1).
The study consisted of a cohort of 77 individuals diagnosed with colorectal cancer, 73 
individuals diagnosed with pancreatic adenocarcinoma, and 42 individuals diagnosed 
with lu

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
vantages (Table  1).
The study consisted of a cohort of 77 individuals diagnosed with colorectal cancer, 73 
individuals diagnosed with pancreatic adenocarcinoma, and 42 individuals diagnosed 
with lung cancer. The participants in this study were enlisted as volunteers in a phase I 
clinical trial (NCT02503774) with the objective of investigating the effects of anti-CD73 
therapy, either as a standalone intervention or in conjunction with anti-PD-L1 ther -
apy. A comparative analysis was conducted on a cohort of individuals diagnosed with 
colorectal cancer ( n = 9), pancreatic adenocarcinoma ( n = 8), and lung cancer ( n = 9) 
who demonstrated stable disease. The study’s results indicated that within the cohort of 
patients diagnosed with epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) mutation (EGFRm) 
lung cancer, four subjects demonstrated a discernible and medically significant reac -
tion to the provided pharmaceutical intervention. From a comprehensive perspective, 
the therapeutic approach utilizing anti-CD73/anti-PD-L1 medicines has exhibited posi -
tive results in terms of inhibiting tumor growth in individuals afflicted with lung cancer. 
However, the effectiveness of this thera

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
oach utilizing anti-CD73/anti-PD-L1 medicines has exhibited posi -
tive results in terms of inhibiting tumor growth in individuals afflicted with lung cancer. 
However, the effectiveness of this therapeutic strategy in persons with colorectal cancer 
and pancreatic adenocarcinoma is still unclear [ 110].
The main objective of the phase Ib/II clinical trial (NCT03381274) was to assess the 
safety and efficacy of anti-CD73 in conjunction with third-generation tyrosine kinase 
inhibitors (TKI) in a distinct cohort of patients diagnosed with advanced EGFRm lung 
cancer who had received prior treatment. A group consisting of five persons had therapy 
with a dosage of 1500 mg of anti-CD73 antibody, resulting in a clinical benefit/response 
rate of 75% and an objective response rate of 25%. On the other hand, a group consisting 
of 21 participants who were administered a dosage of 3000 mg of anti-CD73 antibody 
demonstrated a clinical benefit/response rate of 82.4% and an objective response rate of 
11.8%. The group of patients who were administered a larger dosage of anti-CD73 exhib -
ited a median duration of progression-free survival of 7.4 months, whereas the group

The primary aim of the clinical trial, which was registered with the code 
NCT03954704, was to evaluate the efficacy of a bifunctional antibody known as GS-1423 
and AGEN1423 [ 14]. This antibody was designed to selectively target CD73 and TGF-β 
in a cohort of patients who had been diagnosed with advanced solid tumors. There exists 
a notion proposing that the immunosuppressive cytokine TGF-β possesses the capa -
bility to augment the effectiveness of therapy by promoting the upregulation of CD73 
expression via the mediation of adenosine [ 112, 113]. The initial assessment of a group 
including 21 individuals indicated the presence of unfavorable outcomes, which ranged 
in intensity from mild to severe and, in some cases, led to fatalities [ 114]. The research -
ers discovered that the stability of the bifunctional an

e presence of unfavorable outcomes, which ranged 
in intensity from mild to severe and, in some cases, led to fatalities [ 114]. The research -
ers discovered that the stability of the bifunctional antibody in the bloodstream was sig -
nificant. Moreover, the study exhibited a notable affinity for the binding of B cell CD73 
in individuals who were administered a dosage ranging from 20 to 45 mg/Kg. Within the 
sample, including 17 patients who underwent the initial response assessment, the find -
ings revealed that 4.8% of the participants showed a partial response, 33.3% exhibited 
stable disease, and 42.9% experienced disease progression [ 114].
9 Limitations
The therapeutic strategy of selectively targeting CD39 and CD73 demonstrates promise 
because it has the ability to enhance the buildup of extracellular ATP while simultane -
ously reducing the levels of extracellular adenosine. The aforementioned phenomenon of 
dual action is of significant importance in the progression of a robust immune response 
against cancer. However, it is imperative to acknowledge the limitations associated with 
inhibitors and antibodies targeting CD39 and CD73 in the context of immunotherapy. 
The

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
bust immune response 
against cancer. However, it is imperative to acknowledge the limitations associated with 
inhibitors and antibodies targeting CD39 and CD73 in the context of immunotherapy. 
The primary constraint is the challenge of creating inhibitors that demonstrate robust 
efficacy and safety, as well as a notable degree of selectivity, particularly in regard to the 
targeting of CD39 and CD73. The poor efficacy of traditional inhibitors arises from their 
lack of specificity in selectively reducing the activities of CD39 and CD73 [ 112]. The lat -
est group of CD39 inhibitors, which has attracted significant academic attention, princi -
pally functions by inhibiting the cellular absorption mechanism and only operates inside 
the extracellular environment [ 113, 115]. The utilization of low molecular weight inhibi -
tors that selectively target CD39 and CD73 has been constrained to areas distinguished 
by increased ATP levels as a result of competitive inhibition [ 116]. Furthermore, there 
is a need for a thorough examination of the potential adverse effects associated with 
these drugs that have yet to be undertaken. Another problem that arises is related to the 
restri

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
hermore, there 
is a need for a thorough examination of the potential adverse effects associated with 
these drugs that have yet to be undertaken. Another problem that arises is related to the 
restricted accessibility of commercially available antibodies that are particularly engi -
neered to target CD39 and CD73. The primary objective of antibodies is to selectively 
target extracellular CD39 and CD73, leading to restricted effectiveness against soluble 
variants of CD39 and CD73. The constraint indicated above poses significant challenges 
for potential scientific initiatives and clinical investigations [ 34]. Additional research is 
necessary to explore the unintended consequences associated with the use of monoclo -
nal antibodies.
The complex arrangement of the purinergic network and the significant possibility 
of negative consequences present obstacles to the effective incorporation of adenosine 
receptor blockage in therapeutic approaches. The absence of CD39 and CD73 has been

study was to examine the role of the signaling molecules CD39 and CD73 in regulating 
adhesion. Hence, the potential inhibition of CD39 and CD73 may obstruct the attach -
ment of malignant cells to the extracellular matrix, thereby restricting their ability to 
move, a critical factor in tumor invasion. The inhibition of CD39 and CD73 may begin 
platelet activity, potentially resulting in thrombotic events. The significant academic 
worth lies in the chemicals generated by activated platelets, which play a crucial role in 
the breakdown of the extracellular matrix and the establishment of the metastatic niche 
[117]. Nevertheless, it is crucial to conduct more investigation through preclinical or 
clinical trials to thoroughly assess the intrinsic negative consequences linked to the sup -

weariness, cognitive impairment, increased body temperature, and pruri

mentioned elements pose potential hazards associated with the suppression of CD39. 
Given the underlying assumption that the tumor microenvironment demonstrates an 
elevated abundance of extracellular enzymes, it is plausible to argue that the potential 
advantages linked to these therapeutic medicines could outweigh any probable draw -
backs they would involve.
10 Future perspective and direction
Within the ever-evolving field of cancer immunotherapy, the use of targeted thera -
peutics aimed at CD39 and CD73 serves as a prime example of the discovery of new 
immune targets resulting from fundamentally revolutionary therapeutic approaches. 
The discovery of previously unidentified immune checkpoint targets, specifically CD39 
and CD73, has been shown to hold substantial importance within the realm of cancer 
immunotherapy [ 118, 119]. The primary mechanism by which the CD39/CD73 pathway 
exerts its immunosuppressive effect is by facilitating the synthesis of adenosine

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
mportance within the realm of cancer 
immunotherapy [ 118, 119]. The primary mechanism by which the CD39/CD73 pathway 
exerts its immunosuppressive effect is by facilitating the synthesis of adenosine. Dur -
ing the previous quadrennial interval, researchers have effectively generated monoclonal 
antibodies that have a distinct affinity for the binding of CD39 and CD73. The antibodies 
now under investigation have exhibited a significant capacity to hinder the progression 
of tumors in preclinical cancer models, as supported by relevant citations from publi -
cations [ 69, 119, 120]. Nevertheless, it is crucial to acknowledge that the existing body 
of research concerning the utilization of immunological checkpoints in cancer primar -
ily relies on the utilization of rat tumor models. Moreover, additional research is neces -
sary to assess the effectiveness of specific approaches. At now, there exists an ongoing 
clinical investigation concerning more than fifty therapeutic combination medicines that 
aim to selectively modulate the ATP-adenosine pathway by the utilization of CD39 or 
CD73 antagonists [ 121, 122]. The current state of clinical studies investigating combina -
tion t

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
medicines that 
aim to selectively modulate the ATP-adenosine pathway by the utilization of CD39 or 
CD73 antagonists [ 121, 122]. The current state of clinical studies investigating combina -
tion therapy is experiencing a notable and rapid transformation. In the domain of can -
cer therapy, it is imperative to underscore methodologies that offer a synergistic benefit 
in the context of CD39 targeting. In contemporary times, there has been an observable 
increase in the number of pharmacological compounds that have a distinct preference 
for binding to CD39 and CD73 receptors. Consequently, clinical research was later initi -
ated. There is an expectation that a greater number of assessments will be conducted on 
supplementary drugs in the foreseeable future [ 119, 123].

Targeting the CD39/CD73 pathways for cancer treatment has demonstrated consider -
able promise in both in vitro and animal model studies; however, implementing these 
findings into clinical practice would require an enhanced understanding of how adenos -
ine controls the cancer microenvironment. Nevertheless, one of the deficiencies in the 
scie

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
implementing these 
findings into clinical practice would require an enhanced understanding of how adenos -
ine controls the cancer microenvironment. Nevertheless, one of the deficiencies in the 
scientific community is that adenosine stimulates the formation of cancer by influenc -
ing the cancer stroma; its direct effects on cancer cells can occasionally not be consis -
tent. The comprehension of a range of intricate research techniques is also crucial when 
analyzing tumor inhibition of adenosine pathways mediated by cancer stroma. These 
techniques involve conditional deletion of adenosine receptors or metabolic enzymes 
in immune or endothelial cells, silencing adenosine receptors or metabolic enzymes 
in xenograft or allograft before inoculation, and using a three-dimensional cell cul -
ture model involving cancer cells that constitute their microenvironment. The intrin -
sic impact of the adenosine system additionally depends on an assortment of factors, 
such as the type of cancer, the adenosine receptor subtypes expressed by cancer cells, 
and studies of proliferation, apoptosis, or metastasis. For instance, a specific tumor may 
express multiple adenosine receptors; in th

text:
cer, the adenosine receptor subtypes expressed by cancer cells, 
and studies of proliferation, apoptosis, or metastasis. For instance, a specific tumor may 
express multiple adenosine receptors; in this case, adenosine therapy should take into 
account the competing proliferative and antiproliferative (or pro-apoptotic and anti-
apoptotic) roles associated with various receptors.
Clinical trials incorporating adenosine medications should also be predicated on a 
deeper comprehension of specific human cancers in addition to preclinical research. 
Such adenosine therapy can be determined by biomarker-based tumor surveillance, 
which may involve diverse adenosine receptors, metabolic enzymes, and uptake systems. 
In combination with the examination of possible polymorphisms in the human adenos -
ine system, we anticipate that these methods will enable us to thoroughly investigate the 
potential of adenosine therapy in the treatment of cancer patients. Numerous preclini -
cal and clinical investigations will expand and enhance the application of CD39/CD73 
pathway inhibitors. The combination regimen’s effectiveness with other immune check -
point inhibitors has also been established an

text:
investigations will expand and enhance the application of CD39/CD73 
pathway inhibitors. The combination regimen’s effectiveness with other immune check -
point inhibitors has also been established and assessed in preclinical research. Since the 
generation of adenosine is dependent on hypoxia and cell renewal, it should be benefi -
cial to block this pathway when combined with treatments that encourage hypoxia and 
cell death in the tumor microenvironment. These include hypoxic conditions caused by 
radiation therapy and chemotherapy medications, particularly those that stimulate ATP 
release (a process known as immunogenic chemotherapy). Its broad medicinal applica -
tion may be indicated by the broad spectrum of immunological responses mediated by 
the CD39/CD73 signaling pathway.
11 Discussion
Overexpression of CD39 and CD73 has been identified in many human malignancies. 
The presence of CD39 and CD73 triggered anti-tumor responses, including the inhibi -
tion of CD8 + cytotoxic T cell activities and the suppression of CD4 + and CD8 + T cells. 
The enzymatic activity of CD39 and CD73 also prevented the decomposition of can -
cer cells and the survival of T lymphocytes specific

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
cell activities and the suppression of CD4 + and CD8 + T cells. 
The enzymatic activity of CD39 and CD73 also prevented the decomposition of can -
cer cells and the survival of T lymphocytes specific to tumors. The ongoing discovery 
of CD39 and CD73 in human cancer cells lends credence to the hypothesis that these 
molecules could be targets for cancer immunotherapy. It is possible to disrupt the enzy -
matic activity of CD39 and CD73 by employing monoclonal antibodies, siRNA, and 
small molecules. The inhibitory effects of CD39 and CD73 were alleviated when small 

Page 19 of 25
Yin et al. Discover Oncology          (2025) 16:2153 
compounds, siRNA, and monoclonal antibodies inhibited these proteins. An assortment 
of monoclonal antibodies has been developed that have been demonstrated to inhibit 
CD39 or CD73. The antibodies in question are all monoclonal. One benefit of using 
monoclonal antibodies to block CD39 and CD73 is that antibody medications usually 
have lengthy serum half-lives. Since monoclonal antibodies are injected into the blood -
stream and circulate before they reach their target, this feature is advantageous. When 
compared to blocking CD39 or CD73 alone, blo

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
f-lives. Since monoclonal antibodies are injected into the blood -
stream and circulate before they reach their target, this feature is advantageous. When 
compared to blocking CD39 or CD73 alone, blocking both CD39 and CD73 does not 
enhance anti-tumor responses. In comparison to blocking only CD39 or CD73, blocking 
both could result in superior results because blocking only one already disrupts adenos -
ine production. Combination therapy appears to be a potential treatment option for can -
cer. Nonetheless, research should be conducted to observe the adverse effects of CD39 
and CD73 in patients. The potential negative effects of combination therapy must also 
be investigated. CD39 and CD73 are recognized in immune cells alongside cancer cells. 
Monoclonal antibodies that block CD39 and CD73 may disrupt other biological func -
tions. Tissue-specific monoclonal antibodies must be produced and identified for the 
purpose of preventing this.
A recent preclinical study showed that inhibition of CD39 and CD73 using locked 
nucleic acid-modified antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) inhibited ATP degradation 
and suppression of T-cell proliferation, which is seen with accumulation of ade

and suppression of T-cell proliferation, which is seen with accumulation of adenosine 
metabolites, CD39 was reduced by 98% when treated with 5 µM CD39 ASO and 95% 
with 2.5 µM CD39 + 2.5 µM CD73 ASO compared with the control. T cells that were 
treated with CD73 ASO alone showed a 70% reduction in CD73 expression compared 
with the control. Additionally, treated T cells were able to escape inhibition of prolif -

of 400 µM, which is comparable to what is measured at tumor sites [ 124]. Another study 
showed a synergistic effect of co-targeting CD73 and adenosine A2A receptor through 
antibody-directed therapies. Gene-targeted mice deficient in both A2AR and CD73 had 
a reduction in tumor size (15 mm2 compared with 50 mm2 in single gene knockout and 
80 mm2 in wild-type mice). This result was similarly observed with tumor mass (50 mg 
compared with 100–150 mg in single gene knockout and 300 mg in w

80 mm2 in wild-type mice). This result was similarly observed with tumor mass (50 mg

Additionally, 40% of dual-gene knockout mice rejected tumors compared with 7% in 
single-gene knockout mice. The prolonged survival was up to 80 days post inoculation 
compared with approximately 40 days in the control, and 50–60 days in single therapy 
groups [ 125].
Presently, CD39- and CD73-blocking monoclonal antibody are undergoing clini -
cal trials. Several clinical trials are investigating the use of these antibodies as both 
monotherapy and as a component of combinational therapy. At this time, the results 
of a clinical trial for participants receiving oral osimertinib with oleclumab (anti-CD73 
antibody) demonstrated that treatment-related adverse events (TRAEs) were 60.0% of 
patients receiving 1500 mg oleclumab treatment and 85.7% of the participants receiving 
3000 mg oleclumab treatment. Such reported events were generally mild with the most 
common including rash, stomatitis, diarrhea and paronychia. Additionally, for patients 
who received 3000 mg olec

common including rash, stomatitis, diarrhea and paronychia. Additionally, for patients 
who received 3000 mg oleclumab treatment, the median progression-free survival was 
7.4 months and the median overall survival was 24.8 months. The performance of 3000 
mg oleclumab regiment as both a safe and effective immunotherapeutic agent has since

This finding is critical since advanced-stage cancers is regularly able to generate resis -
tance to the current standard of care, which requires additional therapeutic agents in 
combination therapy to maximize positive outcomes in such cases [ 127]. Meanwhile, 
55 patients with advanced solid tumors enrolled in a phase 1 dose-escalation study of 
SRF617 (anti-CD39 antibody) demonstrated that the most treatment-emergent adverse 
effect in monotherapy were fatigue (35%), nausea (22%), and constipation (19%). The 
most common adverse effects in combination with pembrolizumab (anti-PD1) were 
pruritus (33%)

ent-emergent adverse 
effect in monotherapy were fatigue (35%), nausea (22%), and constipation (19%). The 
most common adverse effects in combination with pembrolizumab (anti-PD1) were 
pruritus (33%), diarrhea, myalgia, anemia, cough, and dizziness (22%, each) [ 109]. In 
addition, IPH5201 (anti-CD39 antibody) was administered to 57 patients and was gener -
ally well-tolerated as monotherapy or when used in combination with dupilumab; 66.7% 
of patients has TRAEs, and the most common events were reactions to infusion (21.1%) 
and fatigue (17.5%). Median PFS was 1.4 months and median OS was 8.2 months; 22 
(38%) patients had stable disease but no patient was observed to have a partial or com -
plete response [ 128].
12 Conclusion
The existing comprehension of the therapeutic capacity of CD39 and CD73-targeted 
therapy in individuals with cancer is limited, despite the significant anti-cancer efficacy 
observed in preclinical experiments when employed alongside immune checkpoint 
inhibition or agonist immunotherapies. Moreover, it is plausible to consider the utili -
zation of therapeutic approaches to specifically address the succeeding series of occur -
rences specifically by modu

source: pmc\Cancer immunotherapy by adenosinergic CD39 and CD73 as emerging immune checkpoin.pdf
text:
tion or agonist immunotherapies. Moreover, it is plausible to consider the utili -
zation of therapeutic approaches to specifically address the succeeding series of occur -
rences specifically by modulating the functioning of adenosine deaminase. This can be 
accomplished by manipulating adenosine metabolism, which is mediated by CD39 and 
CD73. To assess the potential therapeutic advantages of targeting the adenosinergic axis 
facilitated by CD39 and CD73 in patients with aggressive malignancies, it is impera -
tive to carry out continuous clinical trials that encompass a comprehensive examina -
tion of CD39 and CD73 expression, their respective functionalities, and the subsequent 
cascade of events occurring within the tumor microenvironment. Currently, ongoing 
clinical trials are being conducted to assess the effectiveness of anti-CD39 and anti-
CD73 treatment. Future research should focus on detailed mechanistic studies and bio -
marker-driven patient stratification to elucidate synergistic interactions in combination 
therapies.

PNAS  2024  Vol. 121  No. 4  e2315925121  https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2315925121    1 of 11RESEARCH ARTICLE  | 
Significance
Fusion- negative 
rhabdomyosarcoma (FN- RMS) 
accounts for more than 80% of 
all rhabdomyosarcoma cases. 
However, the mechanisms 
driving FN - RMS remain poorly 
understood, resulting in limited 
therapeutic strategies. We 
identified CD73, a cell membrane 
5′ ectonucleotidase, as a TWIST2 
regulated gene contributing to 
the pathogenesis of FN - RMS. We 
show that knockdown of CD73 
decreased FN- RMS pathogenic 
growth in vitro and in vivo. 
Moreover, CD73 knockdown 
induced cell cycle arrest and 
decreased migration while 
initiating the myogenic program 
in FN - RMS cells. We also showed 
that the role of CD73 in FN - RMS 
is mediated by its enzymatic 
activity and the activation of the 
purinergic signaling pathway. 
Our results warrant 
consideration of CD73 as a 
potential therapeutic target in 
FN- RMS.

CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion- negative 
rhabdomyosarcoma through the purinergic signaling pathway
Karla Cano Hernandeza,b, Akansha M. Shaha,b, Victor A. Lopeza, Vincent S. Tagliabraccia,b,c,d, Kenian Chene, Lin Xue, Rhonda Bassel - Dubya,b,  
Eric N. Olsona,b,1, and Ning Liua,b,1
Contributed by Eric N. Olson; received September 18, 2023; accepted November

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
za, Vincent S. Tagliabraccia,b,c,d, Kenian Chene, Lin Xue, Rhonda Bassel - Dubya,b,  
Eric N. Olsona,b,1, and Ning Liua,b,1
Contributed by Eric N. Olson; received September 18, 2023; accepted November 29, 2023; reviewed by Michael Kyba and Thomas A. Rando
Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is the most common type of soft tissue sarcoma in children 
and adolescents. Fusion- negative RMS (FN- RMS) accounts for more than 80% of all 
RMS cases. The long - term event - free survival rate for patients with high - grade FN - RMS 
is below 30%, highlighting the need for improved therapeutic strategies. CD73 is a 5′ 
ectonucleotidase that hydrolyzes AMP to adenosine and regulates the purinergic sign-
aling pathway. We found that CD73 is elevated in FN- RMS tumors that express high 
levels of TWIST2. While high expression of CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of 
multiple cancers, its role in FN- RMS has not been investigated. We found that CD73 
knockdown decreased FN- RMS cell growth while up- regulating the myogenic differ-
entiation program. Moreover, mutation of the catalytic residues of CD73 rendered the 
protein enzymatically inactive and abolished its ability to stimulate FN- RMS growth. 
Over

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
g the myogenic differ-
entiation program. Moreover, mutation of the catalytic residues of CD73 rendered the 
protein enzymatically inactive and abolished its ability to stimulate FN- RMS growth. 
Overexpression of wildtype CD73, but not the catalytically inactive mutant, in CD73 
knockdown FN- RMS cells restored their growth capacity. Likewise, treatment with 
an adenosine receptor A2A- B agonist partially rescued FN- RMS cell proliferation and 
bypassed the CD73 knockdown defective growth phenotype. These results demonstrate 
that the catalytic activity of CD73 contributes to the pathogenic growth of FN- RMS 
through the activation of the purinergic signaling pathway. Therefore, targeting CD73 
and the purinergic signaling pathway represents a potential therapeutic approach for 
FN- RMS patients.
sarcoma | cell signaling | pediatric cancer | Cell biology
Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is the most common type of soft tissue sarcoma in children 
and adolescents. RMS arises from the mesodermal lineage and exhibits features of undif­
ferentiated muscle cells (1). However, RMS cells are blocked early in the muscle differ­
entiation pathway and lack expression of terminal myogenic markers even

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
ineage and exhibits features of undif­
ferentiated muscle cells (1). However, RMS cells are blocked early in the muscle differ­
entiation pathway and lack expression of terminal myogenic markers even amid high levels 
of skeletal muscle master regulators such as MyoD (1). RMS is classified into two main 
types based on their molecular characteristics: fusion- positive RMS (FP- RMS) and 
fusion- negative RMS (FN- RMS). FP- RMS harbors chromosomal translocations t(2;13) 
and t(1;13) that result in the generation of PAX3- FOXO1 or PAX7- FOXO1 fusion 
oncoproteins (2). In contrast, FN- RMS, which accounts for more than 80% of all RMS 
cases, does not carry these chromosomal translocations, and recurrent driver mutations 
were found to be uncommon (3). Around 15% of all RMS patients present with metastases 
when diagnosed, and the long- term event- free survival rate for these cases is below 30% 
(2, 4). Therefore, an improved understanding of the molecular etiology of FN- RMS will 
inform the development of new therapeutic strategies.
We sought to investigate the molecular mechanisms that drive FN- RMS. Previously, 
we showed that FN- RMS patient tumors harbor copy number variations of

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
the development of new therapeutic strategies.
We sought to investigate the molecular mechanisms that drive FN- RMS. Previously, 
we showed that FN- RMS patient tumors harbor copy number variations of the TWIST2 
locus (5). The TWIST2 transcription factor controls the differentiation of mesodermal 
lineages, such as the skeletal muscle. TWIST2 knockdown in FN- RMS decreases tumor 
growth while enhancing myogenic differentiation (6). Through ChIP- Sequencing 
(ChIP- Seq) and RNA- Sequencing (RNA- Seq) analysis, we identified CD73 as a TWIST2 
target gene. CD73, also known as NT5E, is a 5′ ectonucleotidase that homodimerizes 
and catalyzes the production of adenosine (7). CD73 works with ectonucleoside triphos­
phate diphosphohydrolase - 1 (ENTPD1), also known as CD39, in the extracellular space. 
CD39 acts upstream of CD73 by hydrolyzing adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and aden­
osine diphosphate (ADP) to adenosine monophosphate (AMP), which is then further 
hydrolyzed to adenosine by CD73 (7). Adenosine in the extracellular space binds adenosine 
receptors (A1, A2A, A2B, and A3) in the cell membrane and stimulates the purinergic signal 
transduction pathway modulating cell growth, sur

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
(7). Adenosine in the extracellular space binds adenosine 
receptors (A1, A2A, A2B, and A3) in the cell membrane and stimulates the purinergic signal 
transduction pathway modulating cell growth, survival, and differentiation (8).
In the tumor microenvironment, adenosine produced by CD73 suppresses the immune 
response by preventing activation of neutrophils, T cells, T regulatory cells (TREG), den­
dritic cells (DCs), and natural killer (NK) cells that express adenosine receptors (9, 10). 

2 of 11    https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2315925121  pnas.orgInterestingly, a highly immunosuppressed microenvironment is a 
common feature of multiple types of cancer; thus, targeting CD73 
is an appealing option for enhancing antitumor immunity and 
restoring the therapeutic benefit of immunotherapies (11–14). 
Moreover, high expression of CD73 also promotes progression, 
invasion, and metastasis in melanoma and breast cancer (15, 16). 
These oncogenic functions of CD73 can be reversed by CD73 
inhibitors and neutralizing antibodies that are currently being 
tested in clinical trials (17–20).
Here, we investigated the cell- autonomous role of CD73 in 
FN- RMS progression in vitro and in vivo.

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
nhibitors and neutralizing antibodies that are currently being 
tested in clinical trials (17–20).
Here, we investigated the cell- autonomous role of CD73 in 
FN- RMS progression in vitro and in vivo. We show that CD73 
knockdown in FN- RMS cells significantly decreases cell prolifer­
ation and migration while inducing the myogenic differentiation 
program. Additionally, CD73 knockdown reduces tumor growth 
in xenograft models. We generated a catalytically inactive CD73 
mutant that failed to rescue the CD73 knockdown growth defect, 
indicating that CD73 functions via its enzymatic activity in 
FN- RMS. In line with these findings, an adenosine receptor A2A- B 
agonist was able to partially reverse the effects of CD73 knock­
down. Overall, these results suggest that CD73 contributes to the 
pathogenic growth of FN- RMS through the purinergic signaling 
pathway.
Results
CD73 Regulates Proliferation of FN - RMS Cells.  We showed 
previously that loss of function of the TWIST2 transcription 
factor in FN- RMS cells decreases their oncogenic potential in vitro 
and in vivo, resulting in a global shift in gene expression toward a 
postmitotic, differentiated skeletal muscle cell type (6

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
on 
factor in FN- RMS cells decreases their oncogenic potential in vitro 
and in vivo, resulting in a global shift in gene expression toward a 
postmitotic, differentiated skeletal muscle cell type (6). With the 
aim of finding potential druggable targets for FN- RMS, we sought 
to identify TWIST2 regulated genes that dictate the oncogenic 
capacity of FN- RMS. RNA- seq analysis revealed ~ 1,000 genes that 
were differentially expressed in TWIST2- knockdown xenograft 
tumors (6). Among these genes, CD73 was substantially down- 
regulated upon TWIST2 knockdown (Fig. 1A). TWIST2 ChIP- 
Seq in RD cells, a patient- derived FN- RMS cell line, revealed 
binding sites for TWIST2 at the CD73 locus that overlapped with 
H3K27ac peaks, indicative of an open, transcriptionally active 
enhancer region (Fig.  1B) (6). These findings suggest that the 
CD73 gene is a direct transcriptional target of TWIST2. To further 
confirm that TWIST2 regulates CD73 expression, we evaluated 
CD73 protein levels in RD cells upon TWIST2 overexpression 
and knockdown by western blot (6). Expression of CD73 was 
increased when TWIST2 was overexpressed and decreased when 
TWIST2 was knocked down (Fig. 1C). We inve

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
n RD cells upon TWIST2 overexpression 
and knockdown by western blot (6). Expression of CD73 was 
increased when TWIST2 was overexpressed and decreased when 
TWIST2 was knocked down (Fig. 1C). We investigated CD73 
expression in different FN- RMS (RD and JR- 1) and FP- RMS 
(RH30 and RH4) cell lines. Western blot analysis showed that 
CD73 is highly expressed in FN- RMS cells compared to FP- 
RMS cells (Fig. 1D). In addition to RD and JR- 1 cells, CD73 
was expressed in the SMS- CTR and RH18 FN- RMS cell lines 
(SI Appendix, Fig. S1A).
To begin to elucidate the role of CD73 in FN- RMS, we used 
two different shRNAs (sh1- CD73 and sh2- CD73) targeting the 
3′UTR of the mRNA to knockdown CD73 in RD and JR- 1 cells. 
A nontargeting scrambled shRNA (shScr) was used as the control. 
Compared to shScr, we observed a decrease in CD73 mRNA and 
protein expression in RD (SI Appendix, Fig. S1 B and C ) and JR- 1 
cells (SI Appendix, Fig. S1 D and E) upon CD73 shRNA knock­
down. We then performed EdU labeling to examine the effect of 
CD73 knockdown on cell growth and found a decrease in EdU 
incorporation when CD73 was knocked down in these cells (Fig. 1 
E–G). These findings suggest that CD

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
EdU labeling to examine the effect of 
CD73 knockdown on cell growth and found a decrease in EdU 
incorporation when CD73 was knocked down in these cells (Fig. 1 
E–G). These findings suggest that CD73 promotes FN- RMS cell 
proliferation.CD73 Knockdown Reduces FN - RMS Oncogenic Potential In Vitro.  
To further study the function of CD73 in FN- RMS pathogenesis, 
we generated a stable RD cell line with doxycycline (Dox)- inducible 
shRNA targeting CD73 (ish- CD73) (Fig. 2A). qRT- PCR and 
Western blot analysis confirmed efficient knockdown of CD73 
mRNA and protein in ish- CD73 cells after 48 h of Dox treatment 
(CD73KD) compared to No- Dox ish- CD73 RD cells (Control) 
(SI Appendix, Fig. S2 A and B). EdU labeling revealed a decrease 
in ish- CD73 cell proliferation in CD73KD compared to control 
cells (Fig. 2 B and C), similar to our previous transient shRNA 
infection results (Fig. 1 E and F). To control for the effect of Dox 
treatment, we generated a Dox inducible scrambled shRNA cell 
line (ish- Scr). There was no difference in EdU incorporation in 
the ish- Scr RD cells upon Dox treatment (SI Appendix, Fig. S2 C 
and D), indicating that Dox itself does not affect cell proli

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
cell 
line (ish- Scr). There was no difference in EdU incorporation in 
the ish- Scr RD cells upon Dox treatment (SI Appendix, Fig. S2 C 
and D), indicating that Dox itself does not affect cell proliferation. 
Hereafter, we used the Dox- inducible ish- CD73 stable RD cell 
line to investigate the role of CD73 in FN- RMS.
We determined whether CD73 knockdown in RD cells affected 
cell cycle progression, using DAPI staining and flow cytometry to 
assess DNA content. Knockdown of CD73 in RD cells resulted 
in an increase in the percent of cells in the G0- G1 phase with 
fewer cells in the S and G2- M phases compared to control cells 
(Fig. 2D and SI Appendix, Fig. S2E). These results suggest that 
CD73 knockdown induces cell cycle arrest in the G0- G1 phase 
in RD cells. To determine whether CD73 knockdown influenced 
the clonogenic potential of RD cells, we performed colony for­
mation assays in CD73KD and control cells and found a reduction 
in colony forming capacity upon CD73 knockdown (Fig. 2 E and 
F). We further determined that this growth defect was not a result 
of increased cell death by staining CD73KD and control cells with 
Annexin- V and propidium iodide followed by flo

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
wn (Fig. 2 E and 
F). We further determined that this growth defect was not a result 
of increased cell death by staining CD73KD and control cells with 
Annexin- V and propidium iodide followed by flow cytometry 
analysis (SI Appendix, Fig. S2F). In addition, Cleaved Caspase- 3 
protein levels were slightly decreased in CD73KD, confirming the 
lack of apoptotic cell death (SI Appendix, Fig. S2G). Since elevated 
expression of CD73 has been suggested to promote a migratory 
phenotype in different types of cancers, we investigated the effect 
of CD73 knockdown on the migration potential of RD cells using 
a transwell migration assay (Fig. 2G) (8, 16). CD73KD RD cells 
displayed a reduced migratory capacity compared to control cells 
(Fig. 2 H and I). Consistent with these findings, western blot 
analysis showed that CD73KD RD cells resulted in decreased 
expression of proteins involved in migration, such as N- Cadherin 
(N- CAD), AXL receptor tyrosine kinase (AXL), and L1 cell adhe­
sion molecule (L1CAM) (Fig. 2J). Altogether, our findings 
demonstrate that CD73 knockdown induces cell cycle arrest and 
reduces the clonogenic and migratory potential of RD cells.
Knockdown of CD73 Decr

text:
molecule (L1CAM) (Fig. 2J). Altogether, our findings 
demonstrate that CD73 knockdown induces cell cycle arrest and 
reduces the clonogenic and migratory potential of RD cells.
Knockdown of CD73 Decreases Tumor Growth in Xenografts.  
To elucidate the role of CD73 in tumor growth in  vivo, we 
performed xenograft experiments using ish- CD73 RD cells. To 
monitor tumor growth in vivo using bioluminescence imaging, we 
infected ish- CD73 RD cells with lentivirus expressing a luciferase 
reporter (ish- CD73- luc) (Fig. 3A ). We treated ish- CD73- luc RD 
cells with Dox for 96 h to induce CD73 knockdown before 
injecting 7 × 106 cells into the flank of nonobese diabetic severe 
combined immunodeficient (NOD- SCID) mice. No- Dox ish- 
CD73- luc RD cells served as control. Prior to injection, we 
confirmed that CD73 protein expression was reduced in the 
Dox- treated group (CD73KD- luc) compared to the No- Dox 
group (Control) (Fig. 3B ). Imaging and quantification of the 
luciferase signal over 4 wk demonstrated a substantial reduction 
in luciferase signal upon CD73 knockdown (Fig. 3 C –E). We 
harvested the tumors four weeks after injection and observed 
that CD73KD- luc tumors were

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
over 4 wk demonstrated a substantial reduction 
in luciferase signal upon CD73 knockdown (Fig. 3 C –E). We 
harvested the tumors four weeks after injection and observed 
that CD73KD- luc tumors were smaller in size and reduced in 

PNAS  2024  Vol. 121  No. 4  e2315925121  https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2315925121    3 of 11weight compared to control tumors (Fig. 3 F  and G ). Moreover, 
hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining indicated a lower cell 
density in CD73KD- luc tumors (Fig.  3H ). We also found a 
reduction in the number of cycling cells in CD73KD- luc tumors 
compared to control by immunostaining for Ki67 (Fig. 3 H  and 
I). These results suggest that CD73 contributes to tumor growth 
in FN- RMS xenograft models.
CD73 Knockdown Decreases Oncogenic Gene Expression while 
Enhancing Myogenesis.  To examine the transcriptional influence of 
CD73, we performed RNA- seq on CD73KD and No- Dox control 
ish- CD73 RD cells (Fig. 4 A  and B ). RNA- seq analysis revealed 
that greater than 1,400 genes were down- regulated upon CD73 
knockdown. These genes were associated with gene ontology (GO) 
terms related to regulation of cell adhesion, response to growth 
factor, and extracellula

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
n 1,400 genes were down- regulated upon CD73 
knockdown. These genes were associated with gene ontology (GO) 
terms related to regulation of cell adhesion, response to growth 
factor, and extracellular matrix organization (Fig.  4 C , Bottom). Interestingly, the PI3K- AKT signaling pathway was one of the 
most down- regulated pathways in CD73KD RD cells. The serine/
threonine kinase AKT regulates cell proliferation and contributes to 
cancer pathogenesis by phosphorylating and activating downstream 
effector molecules (21, 22). We evaluated whether CD73 knock­
down in RD cells influenced levels of Akt phosphorylation. While 
total AKT levels did not change in CD73KD, phosphorylated AKT 
(pAKT) was reduced (Fig. 4D ). We also analyzed the activity of 
other oncogenic signaling molecules such as MEK, JUN, and 
MYC, and observed decreased expression of these proteins upon 
CD73 knockdown (Fig. 4E ). Phosphorylated and activated forms 
of the JUN and MEK proteins were also reduced in CD73KD cells 
(Fig. 4E ), indicating an overall decrease in oncogenic signaling with 
CD73 loss.
A hallmark of FN- RMS cells is the lack of myogenic differenti­
ation despite expression of master regulator

D cells 
(Fig. 4E ), indicating an overall decrease in oncogenic signaling with 
CD73 loss.

to muscle differentiation media for 6 d. We then assessed the expres ­

differentiation by immunostaining, which revealed positive MHC 
staining in CD73KD RD cells (Fig. 4 F and G ). Moreover, the 
expression of proteins related to myogenic differentiation such as MYOD, MEF2C, MYOMAKER, and MYOGENIN was also 
increased in CD73KD RD cells (Fig. 4H). Additionally, we assessed 
the effect of CD73 knockdown on myogenic differentiation using 
JR- 1 cells. We infected JR- 1 cells with sh1- CD73 or shScr as con­
trol and then subjected the cells to 6 d of myogenic differentiation. 
Similar to RD cells, upon CD73 knockdown, JR- 1 cells showed 
positive MHC staining (SI Appendix, Fig. S3

Similar to RD cells, upon CD73 knockdown, JR- 1 cells showed 
positive MHC staining (SI Appendix, Fig. S3 A and B ) and increased 
MEF2C protein expression (SI Appendix, Fig. S3C ). Altogether, 
our findings suggest that CD73 knockdown in RD cells reduces 
the expression of oncogenic genes and promotes the expression of 
genes involved in terminal myogenesis.

6 of 11    https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2315925121  pnas.orgEnzymatic Activity of CD73 Is Required for FN - RMS Pathogenesis.  
We sought to investigate the mechanism by which CD73 
contributes to the oncogenesis of FN- RMS. We hypothesized that 
the enzymatic activity of CD73 is responsible for its pathogenic role 
in this type of cancer. The residues Asp- 85, His- 118, and Arg- 395 
have been predicted to confer catalytic activity to CD73 (23). We 
mutated these three amino acid residues to alanine to generate a 
catalytically inactive CD73 mutant (Flag- 3A- CD73). This construct 
lacked the two transmembrane domains of CD73 and included 
an N- terminal osteonectin signal sequence (ON) for extracellular loc

source: pmc\CD73 contributes to the pathogenesis of fusion-negative rhabdomyosarcoma through.pdf
text:
a 
catalytically inactive CD73 mutant (Flag- 3A- CD73). This construct 
lacked the two transmembrane domains of CD73 and included 
an N- terminal osteonectin signal sequence (ON) for extracellular localization of the protein and a C- terminal 3X- flag for affinity 
purification (23). The control, Flag- WT- CD73, did not harbor the 
mutations (Fig. 5A ). We overexpressed these constructs in Lenti- X 
293T cells, collected the conditioned media, and purified the 
proteins (SI Appendix, Fig. S4A ). Then, we tested the ability of the 
purified Flag- WT- CD73 and Flag- 3A- CD73 proteins to hydrolyze 
AMP using the Malachite green assay to detect inorganic phosphate. 
While the Flag- WT- CD73 protein released inorganic phosphate 
when coincubated with AMP , the Flag- 3A- CD73 mutant protein 
did not, confirming its lack of enzymatic activity (Fig. 5B ).
