macrophages within them  (45). Our findings , together with other 396 
work following macrophage intermediates separately from mature macrophages ( 43), raise the possibility m any 397 
tissue macrophages  exist in a duality wherein a shadow of the main self -sustaining population, often of 398 
embryonic origin,  is secondarily maintained by monocyte- derived intermediates  that develop into some of the 399 
same mature macrophage endpoints but do not take up residency  and may not progress along the exact same 400 
lineup of intermediates . 401 
Future studies will be needed to further delineate the steps and requirements of the two pathways described 402 
above. We argue that doing so is critical, as it seems likely to us that only the first pathway is operative in humans. 403 
That is, the human peritoneal cavity hosts an ongoing recruitment of monocytes  and differentiation of LCM 404 
intermediates like the LYVE1+ LCM  (31) that we show here is monocyte- dependent in mice, along with a small 405 
proportion of Gata6+ LCMs (31). We were puzzled why the proportion of Gata6+ LCMs was so low in humans 406 
(<5%), while it was so high in mice (31). Our data raise an explanation t

source: pmc\Tracing LYVE1___ peritoneal fluid macrophages unveils two paths to resident macr.pdf
text:
with a small 405 
proportion of Gata6+ LCMs (31). We were puzzled why the proportion of Gata6+ LCMs was so low in humans 406 
(<5%), while it was so high in mice (31). Our data raise an explanation that we had not earlier considered. With 407 
two pathways operative in mice to replenish Gata6+ LCMs, with the dominant pathway being the pathway least 408 
reliant on quantitative replenishment from monocytes, it seems reasonable to consider that humans may lack 409 
this second pathway that gives rise to LCMs in mice while possessing the first pathway that gives rise to a more 410 
modest yield and proportion of Gata6+ LCMs. Human LCMs, even those expressing Gata6, do not express CD73 411 
(31), fitting with the hypothesis that in both m ice and humans , differentiation of CD73- LCMs defines a pathway 412 
for generating LCMs that depends on monocytes and gives rise to a modest yield of Gata6+ LCM. It is interesting 413 
to note  that loss of RAR γ or RXR α in mouse LCMs leads  to an enrichment of LYVE1+ LCMs with many fewer 414 
remaining Gata6+ LCMs in mice . These nuclear receptors  are scarcely expressed in human LCM  (31), so these 415 
retinoic acid -linked pathways deserve att

source: pmc\Tracing LYVE1___ peritoneal fluid macrophages unveils two paths to resident macr.pdf
text:
ichment of LYVE1+ LCMs with many fewer 414 
remaining Gata6+ LCMs in mice . These nuclear receptors  are scarcely expressed in human LCM  (31), so these 415 
retinoic acid -linked pathways deserve attention as possible pathways that  are highly operative in mice and  416 
distinguish LCMs in m ice from those in humans. Given the evidence of these two pathways  and our collective 417 
findings , it makes sense that only the LYVE1+ LCM pathway that generates Gata6+CD73+CD62P+ LCMs  may 418 
rely on  mesothelial interactions. That is, our  findings support the  earlier  proposed concept  that mesothelial 419 
surfaces promote macrophage development  (15), while they also reveal  that the main LCMs in mice do not rely 420 
on such interactions. Instead, in the absence of Gata6, the one remaining pathway  of macrophage differentiation,  421 
enriched in ICAM2+Gata6- LCMs , was simply more prominent.   422 
In summary , thes e studies establish a new model for the repopulation of tissue macrophages by monocytes. 423 
Differentiation bifurcates into at least two pathways that support tissue resident mature cells, one more reliant 424 
on the quantitative recruitment of monocytes than the

source: pmc\Tracing LYVE1___ peritoneal fluid macrophages unveils two paths to resident macr.pdf
text:
ophages by monocytes. 423 
Differentiation bifurcates into at least two pathways that support tissue resident mature cells, one more reliant 424 
on the quantitative recruitment of monocytes than the other.  We have  mainly  focused on this finding in the 425 
peritoneal cavity , where differentiation intermediates to replenish  LCMs from monocytes have been 426 
characterized. Many details remain unknown, particularly regarding the pathway through which resident 427 
macrophages arise from bone marrow progenitors independently of Zeb2, which will be the focus  of future work.  428

Omentectomy  467 
Mice were anesthetized using 1- 2% isoflurane with a flow rate of 0.8- 1.0 liter/min  and placed on a heating pad. 468 
The peritoneal cavity was opened along the  linea alba, the midline of the peritoneal wall, to avoid bleeding. The 469 
greater omentum  was exposed and cauterized through this incision. The peritoneal incision was closed with 4- 0 470 
Vicryl absorbable continuous sutures  and the skin with non- absorbable 5- 0 nylon simple interrupted sutures. 471 
After administration of a subcutaneous injection of saline and the analgesic buprenorphine, mice were placed in 472 
an infant incubator overnight  and monitored until recovery . 473 
Photoconversion  474 
Omental photoconversion was accomplished under general anesthesia by continuous inhalation of 1–2 % 475 
isoflurane with a flow rate of 0.8 -1.0 liter/min . Mice were placed on a heating pad in a supine position. T he 476 
omentum was carefully exposed t hrough a midline incision in the skin and the lin

text:
isoflurane with a flow rate of 0.8 -1.0 liter/min . Mice were placed on a heating pad in a supine position. T he 476 
omentum was carefully exposed t hrough a midline incision in the skin and the linea alba along the peritoneum  477 
(see Supp. Figure 3a) . Saline was applied to rinse the omentum and keep it hydrated. Photoconversion was 478 
achieved by shining a 405nm hand -held laser, positioned at a distance of roughly 5 cm directly above with light 479 
targeted to the omentum for 3 seconds. The midline incision was then closed with absorbable continuous  sutures 480 
in the peritoneum (4-0 Vicryl) and non -absorbable simple interrupted sutures in the skin  (5-0 nylon) . Mice were 481 
resuscitated with a subcutaneous  injection of saline and buprenorphine analgesia. They  were  allowed to recover 482 
in a warmed incubator.   483 
Bone marrow transplant  (BMT)  484 
Recipient mice  w ere lethally irradiated with 800 cGy in an x -ray irradiator with a turn table to distribute the 485 
irradiation across mice. Forelimbs and hindlimbs from  donor mice were isolated, and bone marrow was collected 486 
in a class II laminar flow hood to maintain sterility. The long bones were mec

text:
485 
irradiation across mice. Forelimbs and hindlimbs from  donor mice were isolated, and bone marrow was collected 486 
in a class II laminar flow hood to maintain sterility. The long bones were mechanically separated from the muscles 487 
and placed in RPMI -1640 with 5% FBS to maintain cell viability. They were then soaked in 70% ethanol for 488 
sterilization  and returned to RPMI -1640 with 5% FBS. Both ends of the bone were cut to expose the internal  489 
bone marrow, which was flushed from both ends with a 26- G needle attached to a 10 m l syringe containing 490 
RPMI -1640 with 5% FBS into a tissue -culture treated 100- mm dish. The bone marrow cells were disaggregated 491 
by mixing with a syringe fitted with a 16 -G needle. To remove remaining bone fragments, the cell suspension 492 
was passed through a 100- μm filter. The cells were centrifuged at 500 x g for 10 minutes at 4°C  and counted. 493 
The cells were centrifuged again at the same settings and resuspended in sterile HBSS for retro-orbital venous  494 
injection.  The cell concentration was adjusted such that each mouse received at least 5 million bone marrow 495 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license availab

Peritoneal or alveolar  cells were retrieved by flushing the peritoneal cavity or the bronchoalveolar  with 5  ml PBS 500 
containing 2  mM EDTA. For acute peritonitis, mice were injected intraperitoneally with 10 µg or 1 mg zymosan 501 
(Sigma cat#Z4250) 3 h before analysis. Cells were then centrifuged and resuspended in flow buffer (PBS 502 
containing 1%  BSA and 2 mM EDTA). Blood was collected in eppendorf tubes containing 15  µl of 500  mM EDTA 503

and red blood cells were lysed using BD PharmLyse lysis buffer. Omentum and mesentery samples were 504 
collected, washed in PBS, and subsequently digested for 45 min at 37°C using Collagenase IV (1  mg/mL) and 505 
DNAse I (100 µg/m l) diluted in PBS containing 1% BSA. Cell suspensions were further homogenized using a 506

containing 5  ml of 0.25% Trypsin -EDTA (cat# 25200056) solution and incubated at 37°C with agitation for 10  510 
minutes , as previously described (49). The resulting cell  suspension was then filtered on a 70- µm cell strainer , 511 
briefly vortexed to avoid cellular adhesion and washed twice with PBS.  For quantification of peritoneal c

Livers were collected based on our previously published protocol.  The liver was perfused with PBS through the 516

enzymatic activities. Hepatocytes were
